rules.prover9_expression: (faces(startup, supply_chain_issues) -> (-(receives(startup, regulatory_approval) -> expands(startup, to_new_markets)) -> pivots(startup, to_b2b_model)))
rules.natural: If the startup faces supply chain issues, then under the condition that regulatory approval not leading to market expansion occurs, the startup pivots to a B2B business model.
Either the startup faces supply chain issues or the startup experiences technical glitches.

rules.prover9_expression: (experiences(startup, technical_glitches) -> (-(receives(startup, regulatory_approval) -> expands(startup, to_new_markets)) -> pivots(startup, to_b2b_model)))
rules.natural: If the startup experiences technical glitches, then should regulatory approval not result in market expansion, the startup pivots to a B2B business model.
Either the startup acquires a competing company or, if the startup has initial investment funding, then the startup becomes profitable.
If the startup develops a mobile application, then the startup becomes profitable.
Either the startup develops a mobile application or the startup launches a gardening service.
If the startup hires an expert botanist, then the startup creates a comprehensive plant database.
If the startup partners with a hardware manufacturer, then whenever the startup creates a comprehensive plant database and the startup launches a gardening service, the startup becomes profitable.
Either the startup partners with a hardware manufacturer or the startup develops smart sensors in-house.
If the startup develops smart sensors in-house, then given that the startup creates a comprehensive plant database and the startup launches a gardening service, the startup becomes profitable.
Either the startup receives regulatory approval or the startup becomes profitable.

facts.natural: The startup has initial investment funding.
The startup hires an expert botanist.
The startup does not expand to new markets.
The startup does not pivot to a B2B business model.
The startup does not acquire a competing company.

steps.natural: If the startup has initial investment funding, then the startup becomes profitable.
If the startup creates a comprehensive plant database, then provided that the startup launches a gardening service, the startup becomes profitable.
If the startup hires an expert botanist, then when the startup launches a gardening service, the startup becomes profitable.
If the startup launches a gardening service, then the startup becomes profitable.
Should regulatory approval not lead to market expansion, then the startup pivots to a B2B business model.
If the startup receives regulatory approval, then the startup expands to new markets.
The startup does not receive regulatory approval.

natural_facts.A10: The startup expands to new markets
natural_facts.A11: The startup pivots to a B2B business model
natural_facts.A12: The startup faces supply chain issues

(A1 → G).natural: If the startup has initial investment funding, then the startup becomes profitable.

(A12 → (¬(A9 → A10) → A11)).prover9_expression: (faces(startup, supply_chain_issues) -> (-(receives(startup, regulatory_approval) -> expands(startup, to_new_markets)) -> pivots(startup, to_b2b_model)))
(A12 → (¬(A9 → A10) → A11)).natural: If the startup faces supply chain issues, then under the condition that regulatory approval not leading to market expansion occurs, the startup pivots to a B2B business model.

(A12 ∨ A13).natural: Either the startup faces supply chain issues or the startup experiences technical glitches.

(A13 → (¬(A9 → A10) → A11)).prover9_expression: (experiences(startup, technical_glitches) -> (-(receives(startup, regulatory_approval) -> expands(startup, to_new_markets)) -> pivots(startup, to_b2b_model)))
(A13 → (¬(A9 → A10) → A11)).natural: If the startup experiences technical glitches, then should regulatory approval not result in market expansion, the startup pivots to a B2B business model.

(A2 ∨ (A1 → G)).natural: Either the startup acquires a competing company or, if the startup has initial investment funding, then the startup becomes profitable.

(A3 → G).natural: If the startup develops a mobile application, then the startup becomes profitable.

(A3 ∨ A4).natural: Either the startup develops a mobile application or the startup launches a gardening service.

(A4 → G).natural: If the startup launches a gardening service, then the startup becomes profitable.

(A5 → (A4 → G)).natural: If the startup hires an expert botanist, then when the startup launches a gardening service, the startup becomes profitable.

(A5 → A6).natural: If the startup hires an expert botanist, then the startup creates a comprehensive plant database.

(A6 → (A4 → G)).natural: If the startup creates a comprehensive plant database, then provided that the startup launches a gardening service, the startup becomes profitable.

(A7 → (A6 → (A4 → G))).natural: If the startup partners with a hardware manufacturer, then whenever the startup creates a comprehensive plant database and the startup launches a gardening service, the startup becomes profitable.

(A7 ∨ A8).natural: Either the startup partners with a hardware manufacturer or the startup develops smart sensors in-house.

(A8 → (A6 → (A4 → G))).natural: If the startup develops smart sensors in-house, then given that the startup creates a comprehensive plant database and the startup launches a gardening service, the startup becomes profitable.

(A9 → A10).natural: If the startup receives regulatory approval, then the startup expands to new markets.

(A9 ∨ G).natural: Either the startup receives regulatory approval or the startup becomes profitable.

(¬(A9 → A10) → A11).natural: Should regulatory approval not lead to market expansion, then the startup pivots to a B2B business model.

A1.natural: The startup has initial investment funding.

A5.natural: The startup hires an expert botanist.

¬A10.natural: The startup does not expand to new markets.

¬A11.natural: The startup does not pivot to a B2B business model.

¬A2.natural: The startup does not acquire a competing company.

¬A9.natural: The startup does not receive regulatory approval.
